author: bargainrt99
title: Lovely staff and support
body:
The diagnosis of breast cancer is devastating to hear. I was in a state of disbelief and felt like they must be talking about someone else. I felt really scared and upset but the clinician and breast care nurses were quick to put me at ease with the plan they had for me and more important told me it was treatable. They reassured me and told me that any questions or queries I had to give them a call.  
The breast care nurses still support me along with MacMillan support center nurses. They all are very caring and do an amazing job, and are always there for you. They lift my spirits on the days that I might be low in mood, they know exactly the right thing to say. They are truly angels.  
The morning of my operation I was anxious and worried about going into theatre and how the operation would go. The clinicians, breast care nurses and even physio came to see me on TAU awaiting my turn to go to theatre. When I was about to go into theatre I got upset and the clinician held my hand it showed the human touch it sums up for me how caring and lovely they are. The hand holding, hugs, phone calls proves how much they care.  
The only suggestion I would make and I would have benefitted from would probably be a drop in group for cancer patients once a week like myself where we could discuss any worries or experiences we had, maybe at like MacMillan centre or in the Hospital? Where we had our treatment which we all come to for our treatment and follow up cake? Maybe a activity group

readBy.name: Chesterfield Royal Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

title: Thoroughly professional and at the same time engaging
body:
Arrived at reception and instantly met and taken to my bed and introduced to my 2 nurses for the day. They were Queen and Elizabeth - 2 memorable, hard working, friendly, knowledgeable, engaging, thoroughly professional members of staff. My arrival time and their shift end were the same by a happy coincidence, so we spent over 12 hours enjoying each other's company.  
As with any hospital visit, there is a level of anxiety, as to be expected, however each member of staff that I came into contact with - be they clerical, medical, catering, cleaning - all of them were at the top of their respective games. I apologise that I can only remember the 2 names I've have mentioned, but the Anesthetist and his team are difficult to describe briefly but to say that my time with them was "fun". Thoroughly professional and at the same time engaging and made me feel relaxed and confident. The exact comments can be repeated for the Ops Room team. I felt that I was not just a patient but a friend visiting them at work. Bizarre I know, but that's how I felt.  
Being wheeled back to the ward, we happened to pass tea being served. As I was obviously nil by mouth, my frequent requests for a cup of tea were treated as a joke, which of course they were. But to stop and get me a cuppa just reinforces my previous comments about caring. Evening meal round off with Victoria Sponge that was to die for, if that's not the wrong metaphor. Eventually recovery over and home.  
Thank you.

author: chassisqr73
title: She brightened up my day
body:
I'd like to express my gratitude to Bethany, who was my community therapist when I came out of hospital after a fall.  
She was very informative and got me the extra help I needed from different departments including the Drs. Bethany was very caring and professional. I was provided with equipment to make things easier on a day to day basis.  
Bethany's got a lovely bubbly personality she brightened up my day, I couldn't have asked for better care.

author: psommer22
title: You guys are fabulous.
body:
This morning when I finished a nightshift at the Royal Infirmary, I had a sudden onset of choking, to the point that I panicked and fled into OPD 5 ( the nearest place I could for help) and sought help from anyone in the department. I was met by very concerned staff who got me some water and as I was choking so noisily I alerted the attention of two staff who I assume were Physios or OTs.  
I would just like to thank them all very much, especially Sinead who was very concerned and caring and helped me with breathing. She is now my favourite person ever.  
I feel very shaken after it and have contacted my GP at her advice.  
Thanks again to all of the staff in OPD 5 and sorry for the alarm.  
You guys are fabulous.

links.id: very well looked after and safe

author: woodpigeonkp38
title: Physio rehab class
body:
The physio rehab class is amazing, both psychologically and physically. Regular physio/exercise structured, under addict and with other people has been fundamental in my recovery so far.  
The facilities (gym) are minimal in terms of what's needed, it's clear that better facilities would enhance the service provided and thus patients recovery.  
The fact that multiple patients can attend at once must also save money, in terms of practitioner time and increase the number of people on a recovery programme.  
Please do more of this type of thing as ultimately it will improve my quality of life, health and reduce the risk of me coming back.

author: Jood Falmouth
title: Dealt with efficiently and with much care
body:
I discovered a lump after my two excitable dogs caused a bruise on my right breast I did think and hope that the bruise was the cause of the lump but when the bruise went and the lump remained - I got worried.  
I saw the doctor and within 2 weeks I had been referred to the Mermaid to get it checked out. Saw Mrs English who immediately put my mind at rest by agreeing that I was probably right in my assumption but still sent me for a mammogram and then an ultrasound to make sure.  
Just over 2 hours later - great news - it was as I thought, damage to the tissue from the bruise. I was dealt with quickly and with dignity and humour - very relaxed - what a lovely place with lovely staff in all departments I visited. Thank you so much

author: Oboe
title: Shocking pharmacy delays
body:
Arrived on time for treatment that was scheduled for 9:00 am and had to wait over two and a half hours for my treatment to be delivered from the pharmacy.  
The nursing team are always fantastic but the issues with delays from the pharmacy continue to get worse with every visit.

author: Maureen1606
title: You made me end a bad day with a smile
body:
Over the course of a week my little boy developed blisters on his tongue, which didn't seem to be impacting him; however over the weekend he broke out in a rash and started to refuse his food, which was very unlike him.  
After a trip to the GP, she was unsure as to what the cause was; so she called Blossoms in Craigavon to see if they could take a look at him. From the moment I arrived at Blossoms it felt like I was being welcomed by my own family. The initial Student Nurse, Maria, was so warm and friendly and engaged with my son beautifully when she was taking his obs. Then the nurse Danielle came in to take his history - she was so calm and reassuring and once again could not do enough to ensure we were both happy whilst we waited for the doctor. The Doctor, Laura-Jane, was just as incredible, completing an examination and diagnosing my son with hand, foot and mouth as well as providing me with all the information on how to ease his pain.  
From there we received toys for my little boy whilst the staff observed him, coffee for me and at one point I was even offered a cot and a bed as he was due a sleep. Having previously lived in Australia, I'm accustomed to a first class health service, and I can hand on my heart say that the staff at Blossoms were just as amazing (if not better) as they knew the Irish way of reassuring a worried mum.  
So a huge thank you to Laura-Jane, Danielle, Maria (and there were two other ladies who provided the toys and helped me with car parking) - thank you for making an anxious trip less anxious and for taking such wonderful care of my baby boy. I hope you know how much you are appreciated - you made me end a bad day with a smile.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: sagittaze94
title: Menopause Service is terrible
body:
I have been seeing the menopause clinic since September last year and find it to be woeful. I'm completely reliant on this service as my GP cannot help me and yet I find the support almost non-existent. I have to chase appointments and when they come through they take no notice of the follow up time specified by the doctor or nurse.  
By the time the appointment comes round it's useless as they are reviewing out of date blood tests. Last time they didn't listen and were just trying to get rid of me even though I still have a lot of symptoms. More than once they haven't put tests or prescriptions on the system resulting in wasted trips and hours spent at the hospital trying to sort it out.  
It's impossible to contact them and any communication between the GP takes ages and is very limited. Today it has taken over 2 hours to get a blood test because of this. I feel utterly let down by the service. I understand that all services are stretched but to wait so long between appointments and then the service to be so poor is not ok.

readBy.name: Chelsea and Westminster Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: whiskeyss43
title: Community Therapy Team - Fabulous care
body:
My care was fabulous. Nothing could of been better.  
I made to feel at ease. I was sorry to see her go.  
She was very friendly. Her name was Beverley  
She gave me back a lot of confidence. I think we parted us friends.  
Fantastic at her job. :)

author: Randolgh
title: It could not have been better
body:
Surgery to repair tendons in my knee.  
Great treatment. It could not have been better.

author: elephantmn34
title: Reached my target 6 weeks early
body:
After 18 days in hospital I was discharged with care package, having 4 visits a day.  
Throughout my hospitalistation there was no structured physiotherapy so was having to use frame + wheelchair.  
When occupational therapy visited they arranged physio once a week at home. This was invaluable. Target by end June was to be walking with one stick indoors and out. The team organised aids to help get in and out of bed. Frames, sticks, commode - about wheelchairs.  
Pleased to report can now walk indoors with one stick unless needing to carry anything then it's the trusty frame and reached myself set target 6 weeks early thanks to everyone's encouragement.

author: zuluxn39
title: I don't feel as nervous now
body:
I attended Dr. Nash at the Hysteroscopy clinic due to a post menopausal bleed. I was really nervous and hadn't slept very well knowing I was coming to the clinic and worried what might be found. I have always had painful smears so was really apprehensive about the procedure.  
When I went into the clinic the 2 nurses, Fran and Julie, seemed to pick up on my nervousness and put me at ease immediately. They seemed to understand why I was nervous and promised to be there with me the whole time, telling me that I could stop anything if the pain became unbearable.When I went in to see Dr Nash, he was really calm and explained more about post menopausal bleeding and the procedure he would carry out today.  
When I went into the room where the procedure took place, the nurses were excellent and talked to me throughout. Explaining what they were doing and what likely pain, cramps, I might have. Holding my hand was a lovely gesture and very much appreciated.  
The team explained what their findings were, reassuring me that I hadn't anything sinister. I have to go back to have polyps removed, but I don't feel as nervous now.

author: chachanx53
title: Helpful community therapy
body:
Over the past 4 years I have been consistently ill.  
Underwent an operation to remove a large ovarian cyst and ovaries causing urine retention + other problems. Then suffered a heart-attack at end of August 22 and less than 6 months after this had to undergo the removal of the lower left lobe of my lung because of lung cancer. I was mentally and physically at a low.  
Jannette, a community nurse, contacted me and offered to assist to try and help.  
Jannette has provided to be of great help with both exercises, physical and mental, plus the sourcing of various aids to help round the house. She is dedicated to helping you regain confidence and mobility.

author: ISS Falkirk
title: Good experience
body: I went to FVRH for a biopsy in my leg. David and Lynda were friendly and helpful. David was chatty although got on with explaining everything and getting the job done. Their relaxed and friendly manner did not detract from the job in hand. They sped through the procedure and at no point did I feel rushed.

author: decemberns47
title: I attended for help with anxiety
body: I had trouble coping with my anxiety but Ann helped me understand very well why I was feeling the anxiety and helped me understand how to cope with it using different techniques.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Darcy281
title: The whole team were kind, caring and listened
body: I was very anxious and the whole team were kind, caring and listened. I had two students who also participated in my care they were both very caring and professional

author: KG2
title: Staff was very understanding and pleasant
body:
Contraception. Took some tests.  
The staff was very understanding and pleasant. Made me feel at ease

author: Cloughreagh
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: My life is much richer
body:
I got a warm welcome from staff when I came through the door of Cloughreagh Rehabilitation Unit and the positive attitudes from the staff was the first thing I noticed. I believe that positivity is a great aid to healing and giving the patient confidence on their journey onward.  
Cloughreagh is a gem in an ideal location situated between Newry and Camlough in a Cul de Sac. Fresh country air permeates the entire building with a magnificent view of the Viaduct and Egyptian Arch. It is surrounded on all sides by a panoramic view of Slieve Gullion Mountain range and the Mourne Mountains- A haven of healing.  
This building is known locally as Cloughreagh Old Peoples Home but the majority do not realise its new purpose- a Rehabilitation Centre/ Short Stay for those seeking to regain their independence post trauma and to go back to their own homes.  
A variety of professionals eg physiotherapy are in place to facilitate individual exercise programmes and to prepare for us to go safely home in a timely fashion.  
The garden at Cloughreagh is an oasis of tranquillity with seating arranged in such a way to capture the beauty of the shrubs. Garden ornaments enhance the area while a pergola laden with wisteria and various roses adorn the wooden structure. A backdrop of native woodland creates a curtain of green foliage. Pathways meander through this mini forest, an invitation for the fit and able to enjoy a walk or to just come outdoors.  
Coming to Cloughreagh post-surgery has given me a new lease of life, I have made new friendships and have gained confidence to face challenges that were impossible to me prior to surgery. I am delighted to know that there is a rehabilitation centre like Cloughreagh to support people in need like me.  
My life is much more richer for having spent time in Cloughreagh.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: skymd96
title: My experience was excellent
body:
The letter and pre-operative admission information was scant at best. There was no map or directions and no indication of any timeline.  
However, on attending my experience was completely different. I was welcomed by a lovely receptionist who was friendly, reassuring and knowledgeable. The other staff were also professional yet friendly. They were attentive and caring and all done in a wonderful manner.My surgeon was pleasant, confident and precise. All in all my experience was excellent - thank you.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: davfz76
title: Supportive physiotherapy care
body:
My mum received some support from the domiciliary physiotherapy care team and we have been really pleased with the experience. She had support from Claire who was really nice, both as a person but also professionally. She encouraged my mum to do her exercises, and I noticed my mum's confidence grow a lot, which is the single greatest thing we could have gotten from this.  
Claire also organised for Mum to have some aids around the house to support her as well.

author: Avaline
title: A credit to your profession
body: I attended yesterday for colonoscopy and although I was annoyed it could not be done in my local SWAH, I was very impressed with the treatment received. Staff were pleasant, helpful, explained everything clearly and were very professional. To the nurse who booked me in, the 3 nurses who carried out the procedure and the 3 in aftercare, I thank you very much. You are a credit to your profession and your employers.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: defenderrr53
title: Not supported by staff
body:
I just tried to book transport for my mother.  
She is 89, has gone blind in the last few months, is deaf, is in a wheelchair and suffers from dementia and depression.  
She has an urgent appointment which we worked really hard to get for her as her Glaucoma surgery was a failure and her pressure is at 40.  
They did the transport assessment over the phone (45 minutes on hold later) and apparently as she has her own wheelchair she can get there herself. So what, she can push her wheelchair from Essex to Moorfields City Road for an 8.30am appointment?  
I found the the staff on the phone to be awful and I couldn't help but lose my temper with them, which I am not proud of. It was like talking to unprofessional robots. What sort of NHS is this and how do you treat the elderly that paved the way for you people? It's disgusting, in my view.  
Mum will miss her appointment now, which could lead to severe pressure issues as there is no way she can get there. I am disgusted with the staff and processes I dealt with.

author: branpn49
title: An extremely lengthy and unnecessary delay
body:
After waiting until the pandemic had subsided we were shocked to find out that the waiting list for the autism assessment we had been planning for our (now) adult son was 15-18 months. We requested the referral, the GP agreed that it was necessary our son filled out the form that was sent by NeSS.  
Our son is unaware of his difficulties as we have supported him to lead a fulfilled life and not be affected by them, therefore he filled out the form to say that he did not have any issues. We submitted the form along with a range of information about the difficulties he has, provided by all those who know him, along with letter explaining that he is not at all self aware.  
After 15 months we contacted NeSS to enquire as to the progression on the waiting list and were told that his referral had been rejected but the letter had never been forwarded explaining this to us, presumably the fault of the GP, although I don't understand why we weren't sent a letter directly from NeSS. We requested a re-referral, which has now been accepted, however the wait time has now increased to 3 years plus.  
This means that our son (who very much needs this diagnosis) will have been on a waiting list for almost five years by the time he reaches the top of the list, and that's if the wait time is accurate. If we include the time we waited for the pandemic to subside as we were asked to avoid anything except urgent enquiries, then it is almost six. Six years of his life (and ours) where he is not receiving proper support and guidance and we really need this.

author: KH2003
title: Made me feel comfortable
body:
I attended for a septorhinoplasty. The care I received from everyone was outstanding. I was extremely nervous and worried, however was made feel comfortable by the team. Unfortunately I can’t remember names, however it was the anaesthetist and two member of staff in particular on night shift in the day surgery unit that made my stay a better experience.  
The 2 ladies made me feel comfortable every time I got upset again, I appreciated that a lot, I was unable to wear my glasses and they were extremely helpful whenever I had to get up and about.  
The surgery went great and I can now breathe properly which I’m very grateful for.  
The full care was excellent and can’t be faulted, the only issue I did have was that the day time staff were not as helpful or comforting as the night staff.

title: Bad practice
body: I asked for a telephone consultation which I received this morning by a very rude uncaring doctor. He actually made me cry by telling me that I should not waste NHS resources! I have a very bad eye infection and I don't think it's unreasonable to ask my GP for advice. I am now left feeling in fear of asking for any kind of help from my doctor.

author: skyng35
title: It was nice to see just how much I had come on with her help
body:
I’d like to share my feedback about the wellbeing service. Last year, I had a nervous break down. I work in a school, and was dealing with difficult behaviour from the children and felt like I was getting no help. I went to my doctor and he prescribed me some antidepressants, which have really helped me.  
A few months later- I was mid-sixties at the time - I had improved but was still struggling as I have arthritis, back and knee problems - I began struggling at work again. I went back to the doctor and he suggested going to the wellbeing centre to speak to someone.  
Lorna was really good, so helpful. I was just really down, and I found her easy to speak to and knew it was all confidential. Lorna gave me exercises to do and suggested I went to mindfulness class, which I have began attending.  
The wellbeing service has 100% helped. I felt that Lorna was understanding and wasn’t judgemental. I have had counselling before and didn’t know what to expect this time as last time I didn’t feel I could talk to that counsellor as well as I could to Lorna.  
Last week was my last session with Lorna and if felt sad leaving her. We looked at the forms you complete together so we can start to track progress, (it was October last year I started seeing her) and it was amazing to see how far I’ve come on.  
I’ve got a lot more confidence than I had a few months ago. I knew in myself I was feeling better but it was helpful to look back on our last session and see it on paper. I thought to myself - oh my goodness I was really low… It was nice to see just how much I had come on with her help.  
The GP has also been super and has said he doesn’t want me going back to work. He suggested getting in touch with occupational health at school as well. This has been useful too. I think knowing I wasn’t going back I’ve been able to pull myself together and I now feel a lot better than I had been.  
It's definitely a service that works well so hopefully continues. It’s done me the world of good. There’s a lot of people out there that are suffering from stress who would also benefit from this service.

title: Appointment frustration
body: I received letter on 18/6/23 from adult rheumatology regarding an appointment you would be sending.  If not heard by the 13th of June 2023. I was to contact you on the appointments number. I have tried this number over 30 times in the last two days to make this appointment. As you have not contacted me I am unable to make any appointment and in whatever way I have tried to contact the rheumatology department through. I have just been referred to the same number which cuts me off and does not give me any options of a person to speak to. I find it extremely frustrating and would appreciate the opportunity to make an appointment with you as requested by my GP.

readBy.name: Staffordshire and Stoke on Trent Partnership NHS Trust

author: Didnt think this would happen to me!
title: Help with back pain
body:
I was suffering from back pain in and around August 2021. I attended my GP who arranged for me to have an MRI scan. After the scan I was diagnosed with stanonis which is debilitating and very painful.  
Physio has been arranged with my GP, and the Fort Centre in Coleraine. I have also been referred for hydrotherapy which has been totally invaluable. Being in the water eases the pain and helps my hip and leg joints to be more flexible. I have a life long permanent disability which has left me with very limited mobility, the hydrotherapy is an immense help.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust
Ulster University, Faculty of Life and Health Sciences

title: Bad Telephone system & very unhelpful staff
body: Rang numerous time surgery between 8.00am - 10.00, after waiting nearly 40 mins, staff pick up the phone and inform me that they are too busy to help and I need to ring again the next day. Very discourteous, unhelpful and unprofessional staff. Pure waste of time  waiting and to be informed I have to ring again tomorrow.

title: Amazing team and support for heart attack
body:
I had a heart attack on Sunday night. I drove to Whythenshaw hospital in the early hours of Monday (yeah stupid I know, but I hoped it will take my mind off the discomfort!) and I was seen immediately by triage  and was on a bed within two minutes.

Lots of tests later and I had an angiogram and a stent fitted on Monday afternoon. They discharged me on Tuesday. 

From the moment I arrived until I was discharged everyone was absolutely amazing. A&E, CCU all nurses and support staff. I’ve never left a health service review before but had to. Cannot thank them enough.

author: Bromley cancer story
title: Made each day a little brighter for my mum
body:
Mum passed away peacefully in front of family at home recently, after her 4-year ovarian cancer battle.  
She was under the care of some wonderful NHS teams. Her GP surgery for initial diagnosis and support and care throughout, the Guy's Cancer Centre team in SE1 for her cancer treatment care, with surgical care at St. Thomas's Hospital. She had over 22 sessions of chemotherapy and maintenance medications. In the 48 months of her care, we were very grateful for the NHS, as they provided the best care we possibly ask for.  
The GP helped her be referred to St. Christopher's Hospice for end-of-life care, and along with daily visits from the wonderful Bromley Healthcare team for injections, we helped manage her symptoms and to help her stay as active and mobile as we could. The day a sleek black wheelchair arrived she was very impressed and in turn, it led to a few memorable shopping trips to the local garden centre to stock up summer plants for the garden!  
Cancer is a nasty master indeed and she did feel very angry that it had robbed her of time with family and to do things in her beloved garden and sewing. She hated the way she was dying but had dignity and courage until the very end.  
As a family, we are in awe of all the wonderful and passionate people that came into Mum's life and made each day a little brighter for her.

readBy.name: King's College Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: thubanyr83
title: She was always on our team.
body:
My daughter was referred to CAMHS for neurodevelopment assessment in October 2020. It was a very long, hard wait to be seen with lots of ups and downs along the way.  
We were finally seen in August 2022 and she was quickly diagnosed with autism. Once the diagnosis was made, lots of support and services became available to us.  
We were quickly seen by Sarah (OT) and my daughter had a good bond with her straight away. Sarah made us aware of sensory processing problems and how my daughter was struggling to deal with these. This was something I had little knowledge in and Sarah was able to help and guide us through what this meant.  
I had a suspicion that my daughter struggled with balance and coordination because she was unable to do some basic things such as using cutlery or ride a bike. Sarah did assessments and confirmed that she probably does have DCD/Dyspraxia.  
The biggest impact that Sarah had was that she was always on our team. She attended TAC meetings and sent reports to the school to make them aware of how they could make my daughter more comfortable.  
Up until this, I had teachers and other educational staff telling me that our issues were down to bad parenting, trauma or safe guarding. Sarah was able to tell the “experts” that all our problems came down to sensory processing, DCD or autism.  
We are now 7 months past her diagnosis and she is back to school full time. She is medicated to ease her anxiety and knows how to communicate her sensory feelings to me.  
We have attended the forest group and have developed a stronger bond. She has also asked if she can learn how to ride a bike!

author: braids
title: The best service I’ve received
body: The best service I’ve received, my doctor and her trainee were amazing, very caring and just lovely they are definitely in the right career. Even the receptionist was lovely, an amazing experience all round

author: tangokq73
title: I felt 100 times better walking out than walking in
body:
I had trouble passing urine and a suspected prolapse. I saw Nicky who went all through my symptoms, examined me and diagnosed I had anterior prolapse. Everything was explained to me very clearly and I felt 100 times better walking out than walking in  
Thank you Nicky

author: KNic58
title: The whole experience was very positive
body: Went to the Minor Injuries Unit at QMH and was treated by a lovely nurse called Lyndsey and her colleague Fiona. They were very friendly and treated me promptly and efficiently. The whole experience - from reception staff to the nurses - was very positive. Thank you.

author: lyraey77
title: Care received in the Clinical Investigation Unit
body: I have been receiving infusions in the Clinical Investigation Unit for the past 5 years. I have received excellent care over the years. I am very grateful for all their care.

title: Receptionist
body: I lined up in the morning for an appointment. I was 4th in the queue and was told that there were no appointments left. I then saw that the person waiting after me was offered an appointment.

author: MSHP
title: I cannot praise the staff or level of care highly enough
body: Just been discharged from ward 14 at University Hospital Wishaw  and I would just like to say that I cannot praise the staff or level of care highly  enough. Also have to mention domestic staff who kept the ward spotless

author: Amos93
title: Tooth Removed
body:
Had a split tooth and used emergency dental services in Dundee. I am terrified of dental visits.  
Dr Imran was my dentist and he kept me at ease and got me through the removal off my tooth. The dental nurse Bev was very lovely and gave me lots of information.

readBy.name: Perth and Kinross Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Happylady20
title: I will never forget their true kindness
body: Was admitted with pneumonia to ward 15. After various tests was discovered had stage 4 cancer. Matthew , nurses, OTs, Physio and all nursing staff were amazing. All very professional, but so kind and caring. Had my birthday on the ward and they treated me like a princess. I will never forget their true kindness. Please pass on my thanks.

author: Newmum29
title: Bubbly, friendly sonographer
body:
After an episode of reduced movements at 33 weeks I was referred for a reassurance scan.  
I have to say every single midwife/sonographer I’ve met so far have been absolutely lovely but the sonographer I met at 33 weeks Amie was just so great. She went into great detail, explained everything, was super friendly and reassured me that they are always available if I ever felt reduced movements again.  
Thank you Amie please never change your bubbly, friendly personality.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Ejb1853
title: Lack of appointments
body:
In April 2022 my supapubic catheter came out and I have been waiting ever since to get an appointment to get new one fitted. They have discarded that first contact, even though I have a letter stating I was on the waiting list. I did see a consultant in Jan 2023 who put me on the priority list and they say that that is my new starting point.  
My own doctors have sent several emails saying how much pain and discomfort I am in with the urethral catheter.

author: Tartsrus
title: The whole process was smooth and efficient.
body:
Got my dialysis tubes changed as they kept on blocking up. I was made to feel very important and cared for as repeatedly asked if I was okay. I liked that and was asked what music I would like to listen to, a beautiful touch.  
Throughout the process, which took around 45 minutes, I felt no pain.  
The whole process was smooth and efficient.

author: Jinty122
title: My dad’s orthotics appointment
body:
My dad was taken by ambulance transport from home to Ayr hospital in South Ayrshire.  
The ambulance staff were very friendly and helped my dad throughout the journey and appointment  
My dad had been very anxious about the whole day and I’d like to thank all the staff we came into contact with that day, in particular James and his colleague the ambulance technicians.

author: trapperst47
title: Two total knee replacements due to Osteoarthritis
body:
I have suffered with Osteoarthritis in both of my knees & lower spine having worked in the care sector for many years, my knees got so bad they were bone on bone & my knees were bowed.  
I had my first total knee replacement in November 2021 at Pilgrim Boston hospital. The surgeon was Mr Raj. Although it was very painful to begin with, he did a great job. The care that I received at Pilgrim was very good, the staff couldn't do enough for me.  
The only problem for me is that like the other patients we couldn't have visitors due to covid rules. I then had physio at Skegness hospital followed by aftercare from Mr Raj & his team. Fast forward to January 2023 & I had my 2nd total knee replacement at Grantham hospital. The surgeon was again thankfully Mr Raj. The treatment I received was again very good. It's not a nice operation, in fact no operation is, but the treatment by Mr Raj & all the staff are second to none. I'm very pleased with my new knees & would like to thank Mr Raj & all the staff for giving me my life back.

title: Nightmare
body:
Called 111 for the first time in my life in extreme pain. Spoke to doctor who made me appointment at OOH at Scarborough hospital. 
Got there 5 minutes before appointment.  At reception I booked in; giving all details.  Was told that the appointment time given was not when I would be seen; I confirmed I understood this.
The waiting room was packed. I waited 1.5 hours before politely enquiring about when I might be seen only to be told the receptionist ( who I saw clock off her shift ) had not actually booked me in. The new receptionist apologised and directed me to a different area. Here I spoke to a nurse who seemed to think I was trying to queue jump; I made it clear this was not the case and explained I'd been told to come to that area and that for 1.5 hours I had thought I was moving up the queue. 
I was told to go back and wait. Which I did. I was finally seen at 3am. I was given a prescription and told to have a blood test but that it would be a further 6 hour wait. I went home without the blood test as by this point I could hardly stand.
The NHS is so underfunded, understaffed and overused. I work in the NHS myself in another sector; I get it. But there was no organisation at Scarborough hospital- it was chaos. 
An elderly woman had been there alone for 12 hours. Parents with small children 9 hours. People who didn't need to be there; swearing and being aggressive. Other people there because they couldn't get a GP appointment. 
The whole system needs an overhaul; I understand this  but there are things Scarborough hospital could do on a local and affordable level that would make the experience easier for patients.

readBy.name: York and Scarborough Teaching Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: aoiy23
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Given all the necessary information
body:
I had a wonderful experience in Craigavon Area Hospital today. As I came through the main foyer of the hospital the receptionist was absolutely great. Everyone that I came across was helpful, friendly, and guided me with all the necessary information. Moreover, there were volunteers available who kindly showed me the way to the specific department I needed to visit.  
The cleanliness of the foyer was remarkable, and it contributed to a pleasant and comfortable environment. The staff in the area were exceptionally friendly and always had a smile on their faces, making me feel welcomed and at ease.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Lynsey86
title: 2 heart issues
body:
Daughter who is 6months old got 2 heart issues operated on at RHS  
All the staff on 1D and 1E were amazing and provided great care. Unfortunately she had a vasovagal (?) episode and went floppy and blue, which was terrifying, but the nurses and Drs were amazing and calm (unlike us!)  
My only 2 ‘issues’ would be:  
After certain surgeries a vocal cord palsy is common, this was not explained to us prior so when her cry was very weak I worried. Had this been explained as a possible side effect I would have been better prepared to deal with it  
She was in quite a bit of pain after her surgery and had to wait over 30 minutes for her medication to be checked by another nurse (although I completely understand why this is done)  
Keep up good work!

title: Core Pathway
body: Some of the staff was very unprofessional and made me feel uncomfortable. I was also forced into a therapy that made me worse and “unstable” they then decided to stopped all support I had also refused to take any referrals from other professionals.

readBy.name: South West Yorkshire Partnership NHS Foundation Trust

author: ggggwwww
title: I will live to enjoy another day.
body:
In June I was tended to by the staff at Ward 34 the Acute Surgical Unit.  
The consultant finally sorted out my problem and I would like to thank him and everyone else involved.  
Unfortunately the supposed simple Urology procedure was rather traumatic and this was the 2nd time that a simple procedure had me visiting the Acute Surgical Unit.  
The District Nurse who attended me 12 weeks ago then managed to complete the procedure, although with difficulty.  
This time I was directed to the Acute Surgical Unit once more as I was bleeding and the District Nurse prudently thought that the hospital environment had all the facilities to deal with my simple procedure.  
The consultant out my ongoing problem and said that he would arrange for further tests within 3 weeks.  
As usual the Ward was busy but the staff very kind and business like.  
I would just like to thank all at Ward 34 who were involved with my treatment, especially the consultant  
I am back home now and the blood flow is diminishing. I am still breathing and that’s a bonus.  
I am feeling tender but progressing towards normality, I will live to enjoy another day.  
Thank you Ward 34 and Mr Jalil.

author: nashirajg69
title: They were very good from day one
body:
They were very good from day one, I was told they would support me for two weeks, but I was lucky enough to have them for three.  
They kept me up to date, carried out all the tests, answered all my questions. They helped me as I became ill and kept falling over.  
I have a care plan in place with my doctor. I am 90% better than I was.

author: Bernadine
title: How physical exercise helped me
body:
I have always been physically active. Following my retirement I joined the local gym and enjoyed a range of activity classes. I played bridge, had a part time job, looked after grandchildren and all of this stopped abruptly.  
In March 2023 I was diagnosed with a life threatening illness and hospitalised. I felt like someone had taken me out of my normal life and dropped me in a completely different one, I was not happy. Chemotherapy depleted me of all my energy and I spent weeks lying in bed. I was referred to Joe, the physical activity coach with the Friends of the Cancer Centre, by the hospital physiotherapist.  
Joe assessed my physical capabilities, getting me to do a timed walk etc. I felt I was trying really hard to show him how fit I was but after the assessment I had to lie down I felt so exhausted. Joe made out a plan of exercises for me and gave me a written copy. He came to the ward and encouraged me to do an exercise program along with him. The exercises were all short and appropriate for how I was feeling. He encouraged me to take a drink, rest between movements.  
The activity programme was short and varied. At first I had to lie down after the 10minute session but it showed me that I could do something. Yes, I was weak but I could see a way through to some level of fitness. It made me feel important and I wanted to try to get back to being me in the middle of the regime of chemo, antibiotics, transfusions. There were times I had to skip an exercise session but Joe never give up on me.  
I did feel this was something I could do for me. I was hospitalised over a 2 month period and was able to continue the exercises via an online platform at home. My life now revolves around hospital outpatients and limited social contacts. The one chink of light in it is the online exercise every week. I look forward to it. It’s tailored to my level, I don’t need any fancy equipment, just a chair, a pillowcase as a resistance band and 2 tins of beans for weights.At last I feel I am improving. My cancer treatment continues and I have no control over that, maybe I can do something to make me feel better at a time when all my usual options are beyond my reach.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

title: My Review
body: On time, professional, communicative, explanatory, considerate, honest, to the point and not, time restricted. This was my experience of an appointment with the Diabetic Nurse. (and previous)

author: Relhq79
title: The team were nothing short of amazing.
body:
My mum was transferred from hospital to Summerford for some reablement to get her back on her feet after a fall. Initially her mobility and confidence were really poor and we really wondered if we'd ever see her back on her feet never mind back in her own house .....but.....the team at Summerford were nothing short of amazing.  
The social care workers, OTs, physios and rehab workers worked with mum slowly building her confidence and turning her in to a new woman! The change in mum (that we never thought we'd see) was so positive; she was back on her feet, back to being mum and loving the friendly homely atmosphere at Summerford. 8 weeks after she was discharged back to her own house and is thriving and loving the independence they helped her get back

title: Very disappointing
body: firstly, it's very difficult to get an appointment here, and finally I got an appointment after trying for almost 2 weeks. the medicines prescribed did not work. i still have the symptoms. i requested the clinician for a fbc test, and she booked an appointment for june 1st. they couldn't find my veins to take samples and test postpones happened twice and finally today, they took my blood sample on june 13. every time i visited, i had bad and rude experience with the receptionists. they are on their personal calls every time. i notice it always. we wait in telephone queue for hours and hours, and now I got to know the reason why.

author: liberatorcm67
title: The process was made as pleasant as it could be for me
body:
I was admitted to Victoria hospital in Kirkcaldy for day surgery. I wanted to share a good story as while I was undergoing an unpleasant procedure the process was made as pleasant as it could be for me due to the lovely NHS staff involved. From the smiling welcome from the student (not sure I caught her name but could have been Lisa) on the ward to the caring treatment from her and the staff nurse (Keren Young) who dealt with me, my time on the ward was as pleasant as it could be in the circumstances.  
Add that to my friendly and expert care and treatment under Mr Evgenkos who I can only commend and thank. I was also impressed by the anaesthetist duo of Ross and Anastasia who also made me feel comfortable and looked after while also explaining well what would happen to me, including the risks.  
I really wanted to add this as I am sure people are quick to complain about bad NHS experiences so I felt compelled to share my good experience.

title: Receptionist was not helpful.
body: I went to the surgery just after.9.30ish this morning with a swollen eye due to an insect bite. I have had many bad reactions to insect bites before. After seeing the doctor a course if antibiotics clears it up! The receptionist was dismissive and said go to the eye hospital. To which l tried to explain that if she would look at my records  she would see that after having an emergency appointment.  I would be given antibiotics. Therefore not requiring to go to the eye hospital.She was not interested in listening to me or looking at my records. On going to  the eye hospital l was looked at and given antibiotics. I was unable to drive myself and had to find someone to take me there. No wonder the hospitals are so busy. When on going to the drs you are told to go to the hospital. Fir something that could very easily be treated at the gp's. I am not happy with the way it was handled and after being a patient who hardly goes to the Dr's. I am considering leaving after being a patient for over forty years because other practices are more patient friendly.

author: avocetqp68
title: A marvellous experience
body:
I had my gallbladder removal surgery and everyone who treated me, nurses, surgeons etc were all very kind and welcoming. I felt very well looked after and safe. I was alone so they allowed me to stay overnight which was much needed and very helpful.  
I felt a lot better in the morning compared to the painful night. Katie, the nurse who looked after me during the day of my surgery was very kind and when I passed out from the blood taking, ensured that I was always very safe and comfortable. My recovery was difficult as I was in significant pain but the recovery nurses ensured I was comfortable and well medicated before leaving recovery.  
One of the other nurses ensured that I had something to eat after the surgery, even when the canteen was closed, which was much appreciated. The two night nurses were also very welcoming and helpful, even bringing some extra snacks and juice in the evening which was nice. They both ensured I was comfortable at night and very helpful throughout.  
All in all it was a marvellous experience and the nurses definitely deserve all the praise and a pay raise for their dedication and hard work.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: silverwarejh38
title: Compliments to reception and medical staff
body:
My wife tripped and fell in the garden and we attended A & E at Aberdeen Royal Infirmary with a suspected small fracture of the left wrist.  
I would like to compliment the reception staff and the medical staff of the small fractures clinic on their pleasant and professional help and support given to us.  
It is the first time we have had to attend A&E and although I know that the department was not very busy, the experience was seamless and successful.  
In the end, my wife did not have a fracture but better safe than sorry.  
Thank you to Lindsey and also the follow up phone call from the doctor who examined the x-ray.  
Again, thank you very much to all those involved in my wife's care.

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: victortd38
title: Providing the best care and comfort
body:
I’d just like to say a massive thanks to all the staff (midwives, doctors and paediatricians) who looked after my wife and our new born and myself.  
We were on ward 68 for 5 days receiving care for our little one and could not believe the efforts the staff go to. Each and every midwife was welcoming, smiling, attentive, knowledgeable…. The list goes on.  
After finding out our child needed to be put on a UV blanket and receive antibiotics the midwives ensured my wife was doing ok throughout her stay as well as provide the best care and comfort for our boy.  
I hope this message finds its way to ward 68 and the staff get the recognition they thoroughly deserve.  
Can’t thank you all enough for your hard work, I admire you so much

author: soiltm38
title: Thank you to the team
body: Welcomed me into the team and I appreciate the support.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: mmac61
title: Very positive experience
body:
I had to travel approximately 40 miles to Omagh health and primary care complex to have a colonoscopy, which I was a little annoyed about as I could see my local hospital (which also carried out the procedure) from my front door. I had to ask a relative to take an afternoon off work to take me to/from the appointment.  
However, I am now glad I did go to Omagh because of the very positive experience I had. From the moment I entered the unit I found every member of staff I came into contact with to be extremely friendly while being professional. Each nurse explained what their role was and what they were going to do. They introduced themselves by their first name and asked how I would like to be called. Their friendly approach put me at ease and helped me relax. The procedure was clearly explained and options given if at any stage I wanted it to stop.  
Throughout the procedure the nurses continued to converse with me and offer reassurance and encouragement.  
In recovery I had a lovely cup of tea and a very enjoyable slice of toast which was very much appreciated.  
I would like to offer a very big thank you to Amy and Gerardett (Admissions), Caitin nurse specialist (who carried out the procedure), Gillian and Anita who assisted. Roisin, Rebecca, Chester and Gemma in recovery.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: honeybun
title: Reassurance, professionalism and empathy
body: I had a colonoscopy, and after having a previous bad experience, this was the complete opposite. I would like to thank Dr Sengupta, Betty and Emma for their reassurance, professionalism and empathy. They were amazing. Additionally, SN Maria for her reassurance and sense of humour. Finally, the recovery team for their care and attention.

author: aquilazx78
title: Caring, compassionate and person centred practice
body:
I went for a MRI at Gartnavel General hospital. The appointment got off to a rocky start when I was greeted by a member of staff (they did not introduce themselves) who I found rude and abrupt to all patients, looking away from us when talking and not allowing me to explain I was anxious or autistic so had someone with me and required direct instructions. They shoved the pre check list then shouted me through, calling me the wrong name, rolling their eyes and leaving me to sit alone with the noise or the CT & MRIs in the background. They also did not give me the direct instruction to sit so I accidentally followed them and as I take things literally, only asked about underwire on my bra so I forgot about the metal adjusters due to feeling so uncomfortable. This really made me worried I wouldn’t tolerate the scan I have waited years for, due to covid and other underlying health factors.  
Luckily for me this member of staff was finishing as I was about to go in for my procedure. Thankfully all 3 radiographers I encountered were amazing and noticed I was anxious and sent me out to wait with my relative before calling me back in. I was difficult to cannulate for contrast but all staff involved made me feel reassured and listened to. I was talked through the whole process of the procedure and supported throughout and it really lessened the increased anxiety caused by their colleague.  
I cannot fault the radiographers who went above and beyond to ensure I was ok after the scan. Their practice was caring, compassionate and person centred which was really appreciated. Hopefully, their inclusivity and positive attitude filters down to their colleagues in future as they were amazing.  
I would like to thank them for making my experience the least distressing.

author: Cat67
title: The service provided was outstanding
body:
My son had been attending Physiotherapy at Altnegalvin Hospital for a number of years on various issues he has.  
I want to thank the physiotherapists on the level of care and expertise they showed in treating him. After a long struggle he continues to follow the treatment plan set out by Geri. She has been amazing in helping my son get to where he is at now. Without her knowledge and encouragement he would not have able to achieve the goals set by her.  
A special thanks to Geri and to Dane, who both helped us and enabled my son to carry on strengthening and conditioning his body.  
The service provided was outstanding.

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: triangulumfy34
title: Wonderful service
body:
My husband is quite a large person, roughly 22 stone and suffers with vascular dementia, Atrial Fibrillation and diabetes to name a few. He also underwent a knee operation in 2019 which has left him weaker.  
Anyway, the problem occurred when he was unable to get himself off the loo, I was unable to assist and I didn’t know what to do. I was very upset and crying so I rang my doctor who put us in touch with the community response team and Red Cross.  
Adam and Kudrin (not sure if I have the correct pronunciation so apologies) came out and helped from the community team. I have never asked for help before, I didn’t know it was even available.  
They were wonderful. They helped him up, walked him around a bit, did health checks and assessed his health and needs. They arranged for us to have a shower chair, bed raiser, toilet raiser seat, Zimmer frame – just wonderful, I had been at my wits end but these people were so caring, helpful and it took a load of me.  
Just wanted them to know my appreciation.

author: William728
title: Lovely people
body: Got a endoscopy test done today, the test went brilliantly and i was made to feel very welcomed which helped me relax. I couldn't be more thankful to everyone i met today, they made the procedure so much more pleasant, big thank you to you all - BJ, Nuala, Olivia, Richelle, Rosie and Logan, you made this unpleasant procedure pleasant and i'm so grateful to have met use today.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: June 23
title: Skin Biopsy
body: Had a mole removed for biopsy, was put at ease straight away ,everything explained to me and after care information given. Staff were amazing.

author: Heaney1
title: All the staff were very attentive and helpful
body:
Colonoscopy under sedation. I was extremely well cared for in surgical ward 2 , theatre and recovery.  
All the staff were very attentive and helpful with all that was required. Wonderful pleasant staff

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: GT49
title: Fantastic, caring and professional staff.
body:
My story is related to others submitted recently and relates to problems following an elective procedure. The problems were self-induced as I failed to recognise the symptoms of a urinary tract infection that caused cystitis and potentially other problems had it not been rectified quickly.  
Substantial pain whilst attempting to pass urine eventually became so hard to bear that I went to my local pharmacy. Me being a man my pharmacist explained she was unable to prescribe antibiotics - had I been a woman she could have helped. She referred me to The Vale Minor Injuries Unit in Alexandria and the duty doctor there diagnosed the cystitis and prescribed antibiotics. Luckily the MIU wasn't busy at the time I attended so they were able to see me but be aware you should obtain an appointment through NHS 111 prior to attending.  
Despite being on antibiotics there was no sign of an improvement in my condition a few days later and my local GP surgery sent out a nurse practitioner to assess me, and she prescribed a stronger antibiotic. Overnight that night I had a major bleed in my sleep that blocked my urinary tract and I woke in severe pain from fluid retention.  
I called NHS 111 and their clinician said I had to attend the A&E Department at RAH Paisley. My neighbour is away on holiday so I called all the local taxi firms and none of those that answered the phone had taxis available so I called NHS 111 again and they arranged for an ambulance and told me to call 999 if my condition or anything else changed. I eventually contacted another neighbour who kindly agreed to take me to the RAH so I called 999 ambulance and they explained the ambulance was almost at my house.  
The ambulance and neighbour arrived at the same time but as I was in severe pain I elected to go in the ambulance, which I'm glad I did. The ambulance crew were fantastic and very observant as my colour and manner were apparently giving them some concern.  
On arrival at A&E they were expecting me and after only a very brief wait I was taken in for assessment. Due to the pain I was clearly in they dispensed with an ECG and a doctor came in to say he was going to fit a catheter as quickly as possible. I was given a pain killer and after a short wait the catheter was installed and the relief from pain was instantaneous. My concern throughout had been cystitis getting backed up into my kidneys with far more serious consequences. After a brief rest to allow the effects of the pain killer to wear off I was able to return home.  
Lesson for me is to be more aware of the symptoms of a UTI. I'd been warned after my elective procedure it was a real possibility and had been given verbal and written advice on what to look for. Sadly I expected that whatever other symptoms to look for, I would always have a temperature and that didn't happen. As a result I wrongly thought I didn't have a UTI and my symptoms were merely due to the original procedure.  
However, despite my stupidity at every step the NHS has been fantastic. I'll be having the catheter removed at the end of June and rest assured I'll be extremely aware of what my body is telling me after that.  
For now I'd just like to record my heartfelt thanks to NHS 111, the MIU at The Vale in Alexandria, the Nurse Practitioner from my GP's surgery, the ambulance crew and A&E at the RAH Paisley - you were all fantastic, caring and professional.

title: Awful
body: Poor service. Waiting times between 4-6 hrs bow can that be “urgent care”. We pay our taxes and have the worst care in the world.

author: moonxq48
title: Compassion and empathy
body:
I’d called on the Tuesday after a close sexual partner tested positive for HIV that day. They had me come in on the Wednesday morning and did the relevant tests. They explained everything to me and made me feel really at ease over everything. They showed the right level of compassion and empathy.  
I am awaiting test results but feel they have made me feel comfortable no matter the result. Jake and the student nurse were amazing.

title: Amazing and speedy service
body:
We had to take my 16 month old to Urgent Care after waiting all day for a call from my Dr's practice. When my childs breathing became worse and temperature increased we made the decision to go to urgent care. After checking in and sitting in the waiting room, my child became abit upset and wheezing loudly. The receptionist heard the wheezing from quite a distance and called for someone to see us straight away. We were so grateful for this.

The medical team that then saw my child were so amazing too, trying to keep them calm in a distressing situation and generally being so gentle. After collecting the prescription,  within a few hours my child massively improved. So grateful for the service we recieved as it is very upset seeing a child struggling to breath properly

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Five ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ GP Surgery.
body:
Very impressed with this Gp Surgery. Receptionists are friendly and efficient. Every time I’ve contacted them, they have picked up the phone promptly and helped with my queries efficiently.

The building is very clean. You can always see the maintenance gentleman walking around getting the place sorted. The outside door is always closed for patients to ring the bell. One of the receptionists then lets you in quickly once they confirm you’ve got an appointment. I think this is great as it avoids the place getting crowded with people who doesn’t need to be there.

The Healthcare Assistant I saw was efficient, caring and very knowledgeable.

I have not seen a Practice Nurse yet, but my regular Gp is excellent. He has always been approachable, compassionate and very holistic. Qualities highly appreciated when struggling with mental health.

Overall, a very efficient Gp Surgery that demonstrates how wonderful Nhs Primary Care can be when there’s great teamwork and management.

Keep up with the good work! 👏👏👏

title: Responsive doctor’s surgery
body: I  needed a doctors appointment again for the third time in three weeks. As before I was able to see a doctor the same day and have a diagnosis and treatment plan.

title: Nobody answered
body: i have been trying to ring ent since 29/5/2023 and nobody answers the phone your given 4 other numbers to try by the voice mail left and when you ring these your given more numbers to try resulting back to the original number that gave you the 4 numbers in the first place my ear has a heart beat that's been there far to long the doctor sent an urgent letter stating that if I didn't hear anything back by 28/5/23 ,to ring them straight away but you can't get a bloody answer it's not fair I could have a serious issue and can't even speak to anyone at the ent department.

author: littlekay92
title: Happy with the experience!
body:
Implant fitting.  
Short wait, friendly, helpful advice, felt relaxed.  
Happy with the experience! :-)

author: A surviver
title: Getting my life back
body:
After having a mental breakdown late last year, I was referred to my NHS Mental Health counsellor Helen, to try and help me manage things. She helped with numerous coping mechanism, to deal with things as far as I could, but also to realise that a lot of things were out of my control and I really needed to accept that.  
We talked about relaxation methods and how to recharge a depleted battery when I was feeling low. She also put me in touch with Diane, a Mental Health Employment Specialist, who turned out to be a godsend.  
Diane (and Younis) walked me through all the steps of returning to a job I really enjoy, but helped to negotiate the best and safest way to do that, with my employers and occupational health. Phased return, disability record and acceptable adjustment all suggested by my winning team and eventually accepted.  
I'm still on the steps of a phased return, still have the guidance of both Diane and Helen, and starting to get back to me, I wouldn't be here without them. Thank you xx  
Onward and upwards

author: Castle25
title: RISE school support programne
body:
My son was turned down for support by RISE because he does not meet their criteria.  
He currently has the following issues:  
1. Waiting on ASD/ADHD diagnosis  
2. School refusal  
3. Support from community social worker  
4. NHS speech therapist  
5. Waiting on Dyslexia screening  
6. Private tutor paid for my mother due to literacy support, handwriting issues and pencil grip  
7. Private play therapy with Waymaker due to ASD issues  
8. Support from in school counsellor  
7. Support from Start360 family therapy due to alcoholic father  
RISE was asked to assist with literacy support, handwriting and pencil grip and speech therapy. His teacher and speech therapist supported him getting assistance.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust
Royal College of Speech and Language Therapists (RCSLT)

title: needs reporting
body: I think this practice has taken on too many clients and can not cope needs to be inspected I am done with them and going to look for some were else

title: Magnificent diagnostics
body: Visited MRI Cardiology Diagnostics today, 13 June 2023 for an echocardiogram and consultation with the pacemaker team. Everything was done to the highest standards, and all the staff were polite and caring. Trainees were present, and one could see that they were receiving excellent teaching. The only slight blemish, which is in no way the fault of the medical staff, is the difficulty in entering the hospital site via Grafton Street and Nelson Street at the Grafton Arms to access the Grafton Street multi-storey car park, even for someone who has done the journey many time. Vehicle entry to the hospital site needs some serious improvement.

author: redpy69
title: Supportive staff
body: Today I was in for an appointment with Laura. Laura has helped me understand how I am feeling and has been there to support me through recent trauma. It feels so good to have Laura there, understanding what I’m saying and explaining why I feel the way I do. I feel safe, comfortable and listened to.

title: Turned away with no empathy
body:
My partner has been to the doctors today, feeling dizzy, sick and unable to stand/walk. He had been given a letter by his GP to attend A&E to identify the cause. 
On arrival the receptionist said ‘what do you want?’ I tried to hand over the letter from the GP which the lady didn’t open and said what you brought him here for? I presume she thought he was drunk. I explained what had happened at the doctors and was asked ‘well what is wrong with him?’ I explained I didn’t know and we wanted to see if someone could help. She continued to be rude and was raising her voice to ask what was wrong with him. She said you need A&E as we have no doctors and are just for minor injuries. 
She had no empathy and refused to even offer any advice or support and asked us to leave. 
He couldn’t Stand so I had to ask him to sit and wait until I brought the car around.
I drove to Doncaster A&E where we received amazing treatment, support and were greeted with a smile. 
My partner is now at home with medication for an ear infection and fluid behind his ears.

readBy.name: Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

title: Appalling
body: This practice now 'functions' with a call centre, the staff of which are clueless but not as rude as many of the receptionists there. I invariably have problems with repeat prescriptions with negative effects on my health.

title: Wonderful service
body: I came in to have c5/c6 operation on monday 6th june 2023.all i can say is every single person from the porters to the surgeon were absolutly fabulous.the care skill and dedication by all at this hospital could not be matched anywhere else in the uk.nothing was to much for anyone and all these people deserve so much more so from the bottom of my heart i will be forever grateful for you all contributing to make me better again.thank you all so very very much

author: Anon132327
title: Has always been a friendly face to see
body: I just wanted to say a massive thank you to Sharon, an Orthoptist at Falkirk Community Hospital. She has been seeing my son regularly at her clinic for the last 18 months, and he has made excellent progress in that time and has now been discharged. Sharon has always been a friendly face to see, remembers my son and chats away to him. She is so good at working with children. My son is quickly at ease and responds well to Sharon during the assessments. I couldn’t recommend her highly enough!

title: My mother's eye clinic appointment
body: We attended today for my mother's appointment. I accompanied her as she's nearly 90 and has limited vision. Mum's appointment letter said to allow 2 hours. It was a little over that but we were not concerned as we could understand that it's a progression between  eye test, scan and then Dr and Consultant meeting. It all worked really well. All of the staff we met were helpful, kind and happy to fully explain anything my mum or I, as her supporter, needed further help on.  Thank you to all the staff in this very busy clinic. All staff introduced themselves and explained what their particular part in the process involved. I was so impressed at their skills at making their users feel welcome and at ease.  Clearly this part is   alongside and together with their remarkable technical and professional skills.  Thank you so much- we were both hugely impressed. We could see how busy the department was this afternoon, but everything seemed to work very efficiently. I could see an awful lot of hard work going on from all the staff seeing all these people, but even by the end of the afternoon, there was still so much energy in action. Thank you.

title: Reception staff amazingly helpful
body: I visited Trevelyan Surgery around 4pm on Tue 13 June 2023 as an unregistered walk-in. I was seeking help regarding an overseas prescription. The reception team were approachable, friendly, helpful and knowledgeable, and they went above and beyond to assist even though I was a walk-in customer and not a registered patient with the surgery. Despite extensive efforts from the staff, a solution wasn't reached on the day. However their advice on what I needed to do next was spot on and in less than 24hrs I have a solution to my original query thanks to the support and advice received from the reception staff. Special thanks go to the gentleman who primarily helped, sadly I didn't get his name but he may have been of East African heritage, if there is a staff reward policy I would like to nominate him for recognition of excellent customer service. With thanks.

author: Marhf88
title: ANP visit
body: ANP visited after a fall. I was very relieved I had a visit. Very thankful.

readBy.name: Perth and Kinross Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Scifi
title: Sent to hospital not easily accessed by public transport
body:
I was referred by a Wishaw hospital respiratory consultant to get a mouth guard to pull my bottom jaw forward. This is to try and help my sleep apnoea by opening up my airway.  
My appointment came through to get a mould made of my mouth. It was for the Victoria hospital, Kirkcaldy. I phoned to see why it was so far from home. To get there I needed to get 2 trains and bus, involving a total journey of 2 hours 30 minutes each way. I then had to return to get fitted with a gum shield - another 5 hours of travel. There was no help with getting there.  
It was very stressful and costly.

title: Very helpful , supportive and efficient
body: I have been registered with this surgery for 60 years !! However for obvious reasons I have more interaction now than in my younger days. I find the prescription team to be 100% responsive and proactive in involving a pharmacist if necessary. I have found the reception staff to be courteous and helpful and GP return calls prompt and effective. I feel that with all the criticism of the GP/Practice service that I wanted to say a big thankyou to all the staff at the Shrubbery who throughout and to this day care for us so well.  I am very aware that there are many problems in other practices but not The Shrubbery - I see they are accepting new patients and for those of you looking for the confidence that you need from your practice I suggest that you move to this one.

title: Credit where it due.
body: Called in surgery Monday morning at 0835, and asked if any appointments still available. Receptionist said yes and what was my problem. I told her and she said would a ten past four appointment be OK, to see an actual doctor at the surgery. Must admit I was a bit taken aback after my previous "excursions". All went well and got referral. This is how surgery should run and let's hope this continues.

author: uniformns79
title: I was looked after extremely well
body:
I attended Perth Royal Infirmary gynaecology outpatient unit for a procedure.  
I was looked after extremely well by Dr Brown, CN Siobhan, HCA Carol and their team. The communication and explanation of the patient journey was very well done. I was made to feel at ease and treated as an individual. The tea and biscuits on a tray afterwards is a lovely touch too!  
It was great to see a well organised clinical area.

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Outpatients is top class
body:
Outpatients has been very good. I am mostly always seem on time and the appointments are quick. In the appointments it is just a quick checkup and if I have any worries or concerns I can talk about them. They tell me all that is going on with my care and I am happy about that.  
The staff have been great. I cannot thank them enough for their continuous hard work.  
Outpatients is top class.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

title: Worst Service
body:
I have been suffering from severe mental depression and chronic physical pain but I am not getting any face to face or urgent appointments. The current system is very inconvenient. You have to fill up an online form, then you’ll know within couple of days later that a telephone appointment has been allocated for you despite requesting for a face to face appointment, which says in between 9 am to 13 pm after a week or two from the date you filled out the form, unbelievable! 

The telephone line keeps ringing with nonsense music without telling you how long you’re going to wait and what’s your queue position number.

Requested for an updated medical record and supporting letter, which was previously issued from the GP service free of charge and now the medical secretary phoned me to say I need to pay for this letter because it is a private work as per their policy?!

It takes literally 2 minutes to go the medical history, change the date of the letter and print but they refuse because it’s not in their job role! They are more interested in selling than giving any service.

Requested to speak to the practice manager and they cut the line off! I had to phone back, waited all over again and I was told that practice manager is busy but they will pass the message to contact me. I also sent an email to the generic email address of the medical centre but not received any automatic acknowledgement. The Glen Road Medical Centre has been merged with the Cumberland Medical Centre but gradually the services getting worse! I don’t know who is my GP doctor as random doctors give telephone consultations, and many of them act like robots and have hardly any compassion. The keep sending text messages to fill out forms to update their records despite filling these out several times already!

author: ORB South Admin
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Have been very helpful and supportive
body:
Delroy and the One Recovery Bucks team have been very helpful and supportive since my release from prison.  
They have taken a lot of time to care for my well being and mental health.  
They have helped me with my script to go away on holiday for a week and made sure that I had a script ready for my return to work.  
Many thanks ORB for all you do!

title: Pharmacy
body:
Not happy that the pharmacy has left my husband over 24 hours without any medication, told I could collect it on Tuesday 13th and now we on 14th and still hasn't arrived on the ward.
All day without medication that is his life saving meds.
Not good enough.

title: Can't get in contact
body: I had 3 missed calls tried to call them back and apparently the clinic was closed at 4pm, when the clinic is open until 5pm. How are you meant to return calls and contact when the phone lines close before they should.

readBy.name: Midlands Partnership NHS Foundation Trust o

author: suncn79
title: An asset to the nursing profession
body:
I have cirrhosis and have been put on a trial of albumin, which has been a godsend to me. I go to ward 8 in the victoria hospital for a weekly infusion. The staff in this ward are absolutely brilliant. Anne and Angela are so helpful, they cannot do enough for you.  
They truly are an asset to the nursing profession

links.id: very well looked after and cared for
